Nr. 1_MS8_Roode Liias imp.course_title: Digital twins in real estate management
Nr. 1_MS8_Roode Liias imp.description: This course explores the field of real estate management (REM). It will examine the basic principles of REM to understand techniques and strategies to tackle with profitability and operational issues. The course is designed for anyone wishing to understand and/or study and of develop the essential concepts needed for real estate, surveying, land management, housing, property, planning and construction. Focused on the best practices and emerging trends in the global and European RE industry, this course helps you expand your RE expertise and strengthen your strategic decision-making capabilities. When introducing digital tools in real estate business, digital twin is a digital replica of any physical object, system, or process, contextualized in a digital version of its environment. Digital twins can help many kinds of organizations – incl. REM companies – to simulate real situations and their outcomes, ultimately allowing them to make better decisions. Possibilities of using digital twins for RE industry are discussed during the course.
topics_covered: Property vs asset vs portfolio management

Nr. 2_MS8_Practical digital twins - Raid.course_title: Practical digital twins for smart housing and decarbonisation
Nr. 2_MS8_Practical digital twins - Raid.description: Digital twins are in today's practice used at various context levels. It can be presented in many forms but commonly we do expect somewhat graphical representation that at least mimics the real construction entity throughout the chosen use case. Use cases are different and as such the information context that is needed, extends from one end to the other at different detail levels as well as with certain precision requirements. All that needs a well-planned level of information need activities. This course focuses onto level of information need developments that covers the use cases of smart housing and decarbonisation. This will be defined through structured information requirements that is attached onto digital model in where certain modelling workflows are explained.
topics_covered: Digital twin technology for smart housing

Nr. 3_MS15- Virgo Sulakatko (17.10.25).course_title: Construction economics for decarbonisation and circular economy
Nr. 3_MS15- Virgo Sulakatko (17.10.25).description: This course introduces students to key economic principles within the context of the Architecture, Engineering, and Construction (AEC) industry. With a focus on construction economics, it emphasizes the significance of understanding long-term macroeconomic trends affecting the built environment, such as population growth, financial impacts, sustainability, and the circular economy. Students will explore shifts in supply and demand from a business perspective and learn how circular economy principles are reshaping the industry. By the end of the course, students will be able to understand macroeconomic trends to make informed, strategic decisions that support sustainable growth and competitiveness in the AEC sector.
topics_covered: Supply and demand theory in construction

Nr. 4_MS6-Advanced DIgital Technology in.course_id: Nr. 4_MS6-Advanced DIgital Technology in PDR for circularity Alok Rawat
Nr. 4_MS6-Advanced DIgital Technology in.course_title: Advanced digital technologies in post-disaster/conflict housing reconstruction for circularity
Nr. 4_MS6-Advanced DIgital Technology in.description: This course teaches students and professionals about new digital tools that can help rebuild homes and buildings after disasters or conflicts, while also being environmentally friendly. We'll look at how the construction industry can reuse materials and reduce waste, which is called the 'circular economy.' We'll explore several new technologies like: Digital Twins and Building Information Modelling (BIM), Geographic Information System (GIS), Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Data-Analytics, Internet of Things (IoT), Blockchain. These tools can help make rebuilding projects more efficient and sustainable. The course combines theory with real-world examples to show both the challenges and opportunities in rebuilding after disasters. We'll focus on how these new technologies can help use resources better, reuse materials, cut down on waste, and build stronger communities. By the end of the course, you'll know how to use these digital tools in your own rebuilding projects. This knowledge will help you work in more sustainable ways and contribute to creating buildings and communities that are better for the environment.
Nr. 4_MS6-Advanced DIgital Technology in.enhanced_description: Digital technology for sustainable post-disaster reconstruction - this course delivers advanced digital tools for circular economy applications in rebuilding scenarios. Technology for material tracking and reuse includes Building Information Modelling (BIM) and Digital Twins for resource optimization, while Geographic Information System (GIS) enables damage assessment and resource management. The course integrates Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) and Large Language Models (LLM) for enhanced decision-making, alongside Artificial Intelligence for predictive analytics and collaborative AI agents systems. Internet of Things (IoT) sensors provide smart building monitoring capabilities, while blockchain technology ensures material passports and supply chain transparency. Participants gain expertise in circular economy principles, material reuse strategies, digital ecosystem integration, and API integration for comprehensive reconstruction management. The curriculum prepares professionals for technology adoption challenges and equips them with skills to implement circular construction practices using advanced digital technologies.

Nr. 5_MS15-IL-ES.course_title: Sustainable and Environmental Approaches to Modern Construction and Cost Planning
Nr. 5_MS15-IL-ES.description: The focus of this e-course is on managing and optimizing the environmental impact of construction activities through the use of construction technology and planning tools. The following topics in this course can be seamlessly integrated into existing courses such as Construction Technology, Construction Cost and Planning, and Basics of Construction Technology and Cost Planning: 1. Life-Cycle Stages and Environmental Interconnections: Exploring each stage of the building life cycle and its mutual connections with the environment. 2. Environmental Impacts on Structures and Structures' Impact on the Environment: Understanding the bidirectional influence between structures and the natural environment. 3. Conservation and Enhancement of Local Ecosystems: Integrating strategies for ecosystem preservation and revaluation within construction projects. 4. Impacts of the Built Environment: Examining the techno-economic, social, and legal influences of the built environment on structures and urban development. 5. Sustainable Design and Planning: Emphasizing energy efficiency, resource optimization, the use of natural potentials, and circular material practices. 6. Sustainable Material and Technology Selection: Focusing on choices that enhance environmental sustainability and reduce resource consumption. 7. Modular Construction for Process Optimization: Assessing how modular approaches can streamline construction processes and reduce waste. 8. Energy Efficiency: Approaches for developing energy-efficient systems and reduce energy consumption on sites, adopting renewable resources, and enhancing construction process management. 9. Resource Efficiency Across Building Life-Cycle Stages: Promoting resource-saving practices throughout the design, construction, and operational stages. Using different scheduling methods. 10. Waste Reduction and Process Efficiency: Techniques for minimizing workloads and waste through modern separation, sorting, processing, and utilization methods. 11. Carbon Footprint Reduction: Considering technologies and skills for tracking and optimizing carbon emissions during construction process. 12. Life-Cycle Analysis for Long-Term Building Sustainability: Implementing technologies across preconstruction, operational, and demolition stages to support enduring energy efficiency and sustainability.
Nr. 5_MS15-IL-ES.enhanced_description: Sustainable construction technology for environmental impact management - this course delivers comprehensive approaches to optimize construction activities through environmental planning and technology integration. Technology for sustainable design includes energy efficiency systems and resource optimization techniques, while sustainable material selection focuses on circular material practices and reduced resource consumption. The course covers building life-cycle stages analysis and environmental interconnections assessment, alongside modular construction methods for process optimization and waste reduction. Participants gain expertise in carbon footprint tracking technologies and life-cycle analysis tools for long-term building sustainability. The curriculum integrates natural potential utilization strategies, local ecosystem conservation approaches, and environmental impact assessment methodologies. Students develop skills in sustainable construction process management, renewable resource implementation, and waste reduction techniques using modern separation and processing methods. The course prepares professionals to address techno-economic, social, and legal influences of built environments while implementing sustainable design and planning principles for environmental preservation.

Nr. 6_MS17_Advanced Digital Tech in CPM-.course_title: Advanced Digital Technologies in Construction Project Management
Nr. 6_MS17_Advanced Digital Tech in CPM-.description: Selected advanced digital technologies (Artificial Intelligence (Large Language Models), blockchain, cloud computing (collaborative platforms), Internet of Things, quantum computing) that are relevant to construction project management are introduced and their applications, opportunities and limitations are explored. The course is purely introductory in its nature and focuses on demonstrating up-to-date examples of applications that have been shown to work as well as exploring the possibilities of potential applications. Students are encouraged to interact directly with the technologies wherever possible, to explore their potential in relation to enhancing their everyday work contexts and also to think beyond current state-of-the-art to future possibilities.
Nr. 6_MS17_Advanced Digital Tech in CPM-.enhanced_description: Advanced digital technology for construction project management - this course delivers cutting-edge digital tools for enhanced construction site coordination and project optimization. Technology for blockchain in construction ensures secure supply chain management and smart contract implementation, while Large Language Models (LLMs) enable automated documentation and intelligent decision support systems. The course introduces cloud computing platforms for real-time collaboration and Internet of Things (IoT) integration with GPS and RFID technologies for site monitoring and asset tracking. Quantum computing applications provide advanced construction simulations and project risk analysis capabilities for complex construction scenarios. Participants gain expertise in prompt engineering for AI applications, collaborative platform utilization, and digital technology integration strategies. The curriculum prepares construction professionals to implement advanced construction management techniques, optimize project workflows through digital transformation, and leverage emerging technologies for competitive advantage in the construction industry. Students develop hands-on experience with these technologies and explore their potential to revolutionize construction project management practices.

Nr. 7_MS6-Pikas BIM for Construction Man.description: The business models and value chains of the European construction sector must change to become the new engine of a green, digital, and sustainable European economy. Construction activities depend on construction information and on how people envision the buildings being created and can describe and communicate them to others. The construction sector is undergoing a paradigm shift from material-centric processes to data-centric processes. Digitalization must be purposeful and bring benefits to all stakeholders throughout the life cycle. Building Information Modeling (BIM) has become standard practice in the Estonian construction sector, predominantly in large consulting firms and construction companies, as well as in construction projects. However, the focus has been on the initial stages of the project life cycle—that is, planning and designing construction projects in the BIM environment. In the preparation and management of construction processes, BIM is mainly used for clash detection, to some extent for quantity estimation, and for documenting the building and construction process. This, however, constitutes a small portion of BIM's potential in the preparation and management of construction work.
Nr. 7_MS6-Pikas BIM for Construction Man.enhanced_description: Building Information Modeling technology for construction management transformation - this course delivers advanced BIM methodologies for transitioning from material-centric to data-centric construction processes. Technology for construction management includes constructability analysis tools and design model preparation techniques, while 4D planning methods enable timeline visualization and construction sequencing optimization. The course introduces 5D planning tools for cost estimation and budget management, alongside BIM clash detection systems for conflict resolution in complex projects. Participants gain expertise in data management for construction, construction technology modeling, and as-is process monitoring techniques for real-time project oversight. The curriculum covers design model analysis for construction readiness, quantity estimation methods, and as-built documentation procedures for project completion verification. Students develop skills in BIM methodology implementation, construction process optimization through digital workflows, and enhanced stakeholder communication throughout project lifecycle. The course prepares professionals to leverage BIM's full potential beyond basic applications, implementing comprehensive digital strategies for improved project delivery, reduced errors, and enhanced collaboration in modern construction environments.

Nr. 8_MS13-Efficient HVAC control and ma.description: The e-course provides an overview of heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems and their control in buildings, focusing on non-residential buildings and their control strategies. The course provides the basic theory of HVAC and automation first. Then, control algorithms applied in different building services are explained and observed in simulation and exemplary buildings. Alternatives and energy efficient solutions are discussed in conclusion.
Nr. 8_MS13-Efficient HVAC control and ma.enhanced_description: HVAC control technology for building energy optimization - this course delivers advanced heating, ventilation, and air conditioning management systems for enhanced building performance and energy efficiency. Technology for indoor climate control includes sophisticated automation principles and building automation systems integration, while heating systems control focuses on Building Management Systems (BMS) optimization for energy consumption reduction. The course introduces ventilation systems control strategies and cooling systems management techniques for comprehensive environmental comfort solutions. Participants gain expertise in HVAC systems fundamentals, automation theory, and energy efficient HVAC solutions implementation using advanced simulation tools. The curriculum covers building management system operations, energy consumption analysis, and control algorithm optimization for non-residential building applications. Students develop skills in IDA ICE simulation software, HVAC system analysis, and control strategy implementation for improved building performance. The course prepares professionals to design, implement, and manage modern HVAC control systems that maximize energy efficiency while maintaining optimal indoor environmental conditions in commercial and institutional buildings.

Nr. 9_MS6-_ML_EPJB.course_title: Practical Machine Learning for Building Applications
Nr. 9_MS6-_ML_EPJB.description: The course is intended for people who want to obtain the basic knowledge for working with data and be able to solve relevant practical problems. During the lectures, the course covers the basic theoretical and algorithmic foundations of data processing, analysis and modelling. The course encompasses fundamental concepts such as regression, classification, profiling, time series analysis, and control systems. Students will learn data processing and visualization principles, along with their software implementation. The course further addresses relevant energy-related problems and introduces appropriate techniques with a focus on technological solutions. Upon course completion, students will possess a comprehensive understanding of the methods and techniques necessary to address important modern challenges.
Nr. 9_MS6-_ML_EPJB.enhanced_description: Machine learning technology for building data analytics - this course delivers comprehensive data science methodologies for building optimization and energy management applications. Technology for building digitalization includes advanced data science lifecycle management and visualization techniques, while machine learning fundamentals cover Artificial Neural Networks and predictive modeling for building performance optimization. The course introduces time series analysis for energy consumption forecasting and fault detection and diagnosis systems for building maintenance automation. Participants gain expertise in data cleaning processes, feature engineering techniques, and behind the meter technologies for energy monitoring and control. The curriculum covers data clustering algorithms for building categorization, control systems basics for automated building management, and intelligent control systems for adaptive energy optimization. Students develop skills in building data analytics, energy optimization techniques, and practical machine learning implementation for real-world building applications. The course prepares professionals to leverage data-driven approaches for enhanced building performance, reduced energy consumption, and improved operational efficiency through advanced analytics and automated control systems.

Nr. 10_MS13-Monitoring and managing ener.course_title: Monitoring and managing energy use in buildings
Nr. 10_MS13-Monitoring and managing ener.description: This e-course focuses on the data-driven energy analysis of existing buildings, planning and assessing the impact of energy saving measures. The main aim is to provide the skills for effective buildings' energy-efficiency related consultancy for real estate owners and managers. The course is based on e-lectures and individual practical exercises based on measured data from existing buildings. Successful completion of online tests and individual exercises is required for completing the course.
Nr. 10_MS13-Monitoring and managing ener.enhanced_description: Energy monitoring technology for building performance optimization - this course delivers data-driven methodologies for comprehensive building energy analysis and energy efficiency consultancy services. Technology for energy monitoring includes European energy directives compliance frameworks and energy legislation requirements for building performance assessment. The course covers residential building energy balance analysis and non-residential building energy consumption patterns for comprehensive building stock evaluation. Participants gain expertise in thermal energy monitoring systems and electric energy consumption tracking for holistic building performance measurement. The curriculum introduces energy data pre-processing techniques, energy use visualization methods, and qualitative energy analysis approaches for identifying optimization opportunities. Students develop skills in energy demand normalization processes and energy saving measures assessment for effective building energy consultancy. The course prepares professionals to provide data-driven energy efficiency recommendations to real estate owners and managers, implement energy monitoring strategies, and evaluate the impact of energy conservation measures using measured building performance data and advanced analytical techniques.

Nr. 11_MS10-.course_title: Development of properties of building materials and computational applications
Nr. 11_MS10-.description: This course is a combination of e-course with online materials and hands on activities producing and testing a newly designed building material. The new building material partly consist of recycled materials. The testing in laboratory is done in teams. The tasks for teams follow CDIO principles.
Nr. 11_MS10-.enhanced_description: Building materials development technology for sustainable construction - this course delivers practical methodologies for designing, producing, and testing innovative building materials with recycled content integration. Technology for material property development includes comprehensive property criteria selection and mass production optimization techniques for scalable building material manufacturing. The course introduces laboratory material production protocols and material testing procedures for comprehensive performance evaluation and quality assurance. Participants gain expertise in statistical analysis tools for determining declarable property values and performance assessment methodologies for building material certification. The curriculum covers recycled building materials integration strategies, computational material applications for performance prediction, and CDIO principles for systematic innovation development. Students develop hands-on experience in material design cycles, batch production testing, and performance validation through team-based laboratory activities. The course prepares professionals to develop sustainable building materials, implement quality control processes, and leverage computational tools for material optimization in circular economy construction applications.

Nr. 12_MS10-Digital tools Simo Ilomets.course_title: Digital tools for auditing building as material bank
Nr. 12_MS10-Digital tools Simo Ilomets.description: Sustainable built environment is moving towards circularity by several approaches. While design for disassembly principles can be applied for new buildings under design, there seems to be notable reuse potential of various structural and/or building envelope elements stored in existing buildings, considered to be material bank for urban mining. According to 9R circular construction principles, refuse, rethink and reduce is a way to go, followed by renovation. If demolition is inevitable, reuse of components should be preferred. Remanufacture or recycling of building materials from existing buildings becomes an option, if reuse is complicated. Instead of business as usual demolition, existing buildings should be analysed against possible adaptions of functionality as well as various renovation scenario. Pre-demolition auditing should be carried out in order assess reuse potential of its elements or recycling of materials. Digital tools in combination of expert knowledge have proven to be useful approach for several purposes and can be combined to non-destructive assessment methods. The course gives broader background and guides participants step by step towards the circular construction of existing building stock by applying digital tools (software, web-page, digital material database etc) and advanced digital devices. Main typologies and quantity of buildings is introduced in terms of stored building materials and resource efficiency.
Nr. 12_MS10-Digital tools Simo Ilomets.enhanced_description: Digital auditing technology for circular construction material banks - this course delivers advanced digital tools and methodologies for evaluating existing buildings as material repositories for urban mining and circular economy applications. Technology for building material auditing includes comprehensive pre-demolition assessment tools and non-destructive evaluation methods combined with expert knowledge integration systems. The course introduces adaptability analysis frameworks for assessing building functionality modifications and structural elements performance evaluation for reuse potential determination. Participants gain expertise in digital material database management and expert knowledge integration into digital auditing platforms for comprehensive building stock analysis. The curriculum covers buildings as material banks concepts, element classification systems for reuse applications, and parallel design methodologies for donor building integration into receival building projects. Students develop skills in design for deconstruction processes, elements classification procedures, and digital tool utilization for circular construction implementation. The course prepares professionals to conduct comprehensive building audits, implement circular construction principles using 9R framework, and leverage digital technologies for maximizing material reuse and resource efficiency in existing building stock renovation and adaptation projects.

Nr. 13_MS12_Ratassepp.description: This e-course provides an in-depth understanding of ultrasonic testing (UT) techniques for evaluating the integrity and quality of building materials. It covers fundamental principles of ultrasonic waves, testing methods, equipment, data interpretation, and practical applications in construction and civil engineering. Participants will gain knowledge about detecting defects, assessing material properties, and ensuring structural safety using UT methods. The course includes theoretical concepts, case studies, and hands-on demonstrations using virtual simulations, including examples of characterization and defect assessment in External Thermal Insulation Composite Systems (ETICS).
Nr. 13_MS12_Ratassepp.enhanced_description: Ultrasonic testing technology for building material integrity assessment - this course delivers comprehensive non-destructive testing methodologies for evaluating structural safety and material quality in construction applications. Technology for defect detection includes advanced ultrasonic wave propagation analysis and wave reflection/refraction techniques for precise flaw identification in building materials. The course introduces contact testing methods and immersion testing techniques for diverse material evaluation scenarios, alongside pulse-echo testing and phased array ultrasonics for detailed structural analysis. Participants gain expertise in UT equipment calibration procedures, signal processing methodologies, and defect characterization techniques for comprehensive material assessment. The curriculum covers A-scan B-scan C-scan imaging systems, structural health monitoring applications, and specialized testing for External Thermal Insulation Composite Systems (ETICS). Students develop skills in concrete quality control protocols, steel structure inspection procedures, crack detection methodologies, and void detection techniques for ensuring construction safety. The course prepares professionals to implement advanced ultrasonic testing systems for quality assurance, maintenance planning, and structural integrity verification in both new construction and existing building assessment projects.

Nr. 14_MS13- K-AKertsmik-1.description: This e-course on Built Environment Sustainability and Building Carbon Footprint, explores the built environment's impact on climate change, emphasizing carbon emissions in construction and renovation. Participants will learn about environmental regulations, carbon footprint calculations, and data's role in emissions understanding. Key topics include lifecycle assessment, the differences between new and renovated buildings, and strategies for reducing carbon footprints. The course also addresses circular renovation concepts and sustainability in public procurements and architectural competitions, offering a blend of theoretical insights and practical case studies and examples. It is designed for students, professionals, and anyone interested in sustainable building practices.
Nr. 14_MS13- K-AKertsmik-1.enhanced_description: Carbon footprint technology for sustainable building design - this course delivers comprehensive methodologies for evaluating and reducing building environmental impact through advanced carbon assessment techniques. Technology for carbon management includes carbon footprint methodologies for precise emission calculation and lifecycle assessment frameworks for comprehensive environmental impact analysis. The course introduces new building carbon analysis techniques and renovated building carbon evaluation methods for comparing construction versus renovation scenarios. Participants gain expertise in environmental regulations compliance and sustainability standards implementation for regulatory adherence and best practice adoption. The curriculum covers circular renovation concepts for material reuse, Product Environmental Declarations (EPD) utilization, and BIM sustainability applications for integrated carbon management. Students develop skills in carbon emission calculations, climate change impact assessment, and carbon reduction strategies for sustainable building practices. The course prepares professionals to implement sustainable architectural competition guidelines, evaluate public procurement sustainability criteria, and leverage BIM technologies for carbon optimization across building lifecycles while addressing broader sustainability considerations beyond carbon emissions.

Nr. 15_MS13- KAKertsmik-2.description: This e-course, titled "Building Carbon Footprint - Reporting," provides participants with a comprehensive understanding of assessing a building's carbon footprint throughout its lifecycle. The course will guide students through a detailed calculation process based on established methodologies and standards, leading to the compilation of a structured report. Compilation of a structured report. Participants will engage with various aspects of building analysis, including architectural components, software tools, and data sources. By the end of the course, students will develop the skills to analyse and present findings regarding carbon emissions associated with building construction and operation.
Nr. 15_MS13- KAKertsmik-2.enhanced_description: Carbon reporting technology for comprehensive building lifecycle analysis - this course delivers systematic methodologies for assessing, calculating, and documenting building carbon footprints through structured reporting frameworks. Technology for carbon calculation includes advanced architectural carbon analysis tools and carbon calculation software for precise building emissions evaluation across all lifecycle stages. The course introduces building lifecycle analysis methodologies and impact category assessment frameworks for comprehensive environmental impact measurement and system boundary definition. Participants gain expertise in material carbon contributions analysis and data source relevance evaluation for accurate carbon footprint determination and reporting accuracy. The curriculum covers system boundary definition protocols, carbon footprint reporting standards, and carbon reduction recommendations development for actionable sustainability improvements. Students develop skills in carbon footprint calculation processes, sustainable building analysis techniques, and structured report compilation for effective stakeholder communication. The course prepares professionals to conduct comprehensive building carbon assessments, utilize specialized software tools for accurate calculations, and develop professional carbon footprint reports that support sustainable decision-making in construction and real estate development projects.

Nr. 16_MS13-LCA_V.Voronova.description: This e-course provides a comprehensive introduction to Product Environmental Life Cycle Assessment (LCA), a systematic approach to evaluating the environmental impacts associated with all stages of a product's life cycle. From raw material extraction to production, distribution, use, and disposal, participants will learn how to identify, measure, and mitigate environmental impacts to promote sustainable design and decision-making. The course introduces the principles and methodologies for life cycle assessment, relevant regulations, and international standards (e.g., ISO 14040 and ISO 14044), as well as related software solutions. The practical part will introduce the OpenLCA software and demonstrate its use through a simplified case study, followed by independent work on modelling a custom product system.
Nr. 16_MS13-LCA_V.Voronova.enhanced_description: Life cycle assessment technology for comprehensive environmental impact evaluation - this course delivers systematic methodologies for analyzing product environmental impacts across entire lifecycles from raw material extraction through disposal. Technology for environmental assessment includes Product Environmental Life Cycle Assessment frameworks and comprehensive environmental impact evaluation methodologies for sustainable design optimization. The course introduces raw material extraction impact analysis and production environmental analysis techniques for identifying carbon hotspots and mitigation opportunities throughout supply chains. Participants gain expertise in distribution impact assessment protocols and use phase environmental analysis methods for complete lifecycle evaluation and impact category identification. The curriculum covers ISO 14040 standards compliance, ISO 14044 implementation guidelines, and OpenLCA software utilization for professional LCA modeling and analysis. Students develop skills in LCA goal definition processes, product system analysis methodologies, and life cycle flowcharting techniques for systematic environmental assessment. The course prepares professionals to conduct comprehensive LCAs, develop Environmental Product Declarations (EPD), implement environmental allocation methods, and interpret LCA results for sustainable decision-making in product development and manufacturing industries.

Nr. 17_MS11-(MS12-)_Fomins.course_title: Photonics applications and lighting solutions for decarbonisation of housing
Nr. 17_MS11-(MS12-)_Fomins.description: This course is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of how photonics technology can be utilized to reduce carbon emissions and promote sustainable living environments. As the world strives to combat climate change and reduce its carbon footprint, the role of advanced technologies like photonics becomes increasingly critical. This course employs a blend of interactive lectures, hands-on experiments, group projects, and case study analyses to provide a well-rounded learning experience. You will have the opportunity to engage with real-world examples, participate in collaborative activities, and apply your knowledge to practical scenarios. Our goal is to empower you with the tools and insights needed to drive the adoption of photonics technologies for a sustainable and carbon-neutral future.
Nr. 17_MS11-(MS12-)_Fomins.enhanced_description: Photonics technology for housing decarbonization and sustainable living - this course delivers advanced photonic applications for reducing carbon emissions through innovative light-based technologies and energy-efficient solutions. Technology for renewable energy includes solar energy conversion systems and photovoltaic technologies enhanced by photonic materials for superior solar panel efficiency and energy harvesting optimization. The course introduces energy-efficient lighting solutions including advanced LED technology and laser lighting systems for reduced energy consumption in residential and commercial applications. Participants gain expertise in optical communications for data transmission efficiency and optical pollution sensors for environmental monitoring and air quality assessment. The curriculum covers photonic devices development, light-matter interaction principles, and carbon emissions reduction strategies through sustainable photonics applications. Students develop skills in environmental photonics policy implementation, decarbonization technologies deployment, and photonic system integration for sustainable building design. The course prepares professionals to implement cutting-edge photonics solutions for housing decarbonization, develop sustainable lighting strategies, and leverage optical technologies for environmental monitoring and carbon footprint reduction in the built environment.

MS7_N2- E-course A Banaitis.description: This digital course is designed to provide knowledge and practical experience in three levels (basic, intermediate and advanced) on the transformative potential of blockchain technology in the built environment. Students will gain insight into the fundamentals of blockchain, smart contracts and decentralised systems, focusing on their applications in improving transparency, efficiency and trust in the built environment. Key topics include BIM and smart asset management, payment and project management, procurement and supply chain management, sustainable practices through tokenisation. By the end of the course, students will be able to evaluate and implement blockchain solutions tailored to the challenges and opportunities of the built environment.
MS7_N2- E-course A Banaitis.enhanced_description: Blockchain technology for built environment transparency and efficiency - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in distributed ledger systems, smart contracts, and decentralized applications for construction and real estate. Students gain practical skills in implementing blockchain solutions for BIM integration, smart asset management, automated payment systems, and supply chain transparency. The curriculum covers tokenization for sustainable building practices, cryptographic security protocols, and consensus mechanisms tailored to infrastructure projects. Graduates emerge equipped to develop blockchain-based platforms that enhance trust, reduce fraud, and optimize resource allocation in construction projects, enabling next-generation digital transformation in the built environment sector.

MS8_N4- E-course S. Raslanas (1).course_title: Digital twins and affective computing in built environments: an investigation of the characteristics, applications, and challenges
MS8_N4- E-course S. Raslanas (1).description: This course covers the integration of digital twins and affective computing to create smart, responsive built environments. Students will learn how digital models (digital twins) can optimize physical spaces in real-time, while affective computing adapts environments to human emotions for improved user experience. The course provides introduction to basics of Digital Twins and Affective Computing, Creating and managing digital models of buildings and cities, using emotional AI to design responsive spaces (lighting, HVAC, etc.), ethical considerations in data collection and system design.
MS8_N4- E-course S. Raslanas (1).enhanced_description: Digital twin technology for responsive built environments and human-centered spaces - this course delivers expertise in creating virtual replicas of physical structures integrated with emotional AI systems for adaptive architecture. Students master digital modeling techniques, real-time data synchronization, and affective computing algorithms that enable buildings to respond to human emotions and behavior patterns. The curriculum covers sensor integration, emotional AI implementation, dynamic environmental controls, and ethical frameworks for emotion-sensitive design. Graduates emerge skilled in developing intelligent spaces that automatically adjust lighting, temperature, and spatial configurations based on occupant psychological states, revolutionizing how buildings interact with their inhabitants and creating truly responsive architectural experiences.

MS16_N5- E-course L. Tupenaite.course_title: Adaptable and affordable housing for climate change adaptation
MS16_N5- E-course L. Tupenaite.description: It is estimated that by 2050, the urban population will grow by another 2.5 billion. Climate action must start with housing because of its direct impact on people's health and livelihood. Building resilient and affordable homes for climate adaptation involves designing and building houses that can withstand and adapt to the challenges presented by climate change, and ensuring the safety and well-being of occupants. This digital course is designed to provide knowledge and practical skills in adaptable and affordable housing design solutions. It begins with the understanding about the role of housing against climate change, and further reviews a variety of solutions that can be used in design of adaptable housing, i.e., building with natural materials, installation of renewable energy systems, rainwater harvesting systems, waste-to-energy conversion. At the end of the course, community engagement is discussed and economic feasibility in terms of housing affordability is evaluated.
MS16_N5- E-course L. Tupenaite.enhanced_description: Climate-adaptive housing technology for resilient urban communities - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in designing and constructing affordable homes that withstand climate change challenges while promoting sustainable living. Students master natural building techniques including timber-based structures, green roof technology, and climate-resilient construction methods. The curriculum covers renewable energy integration, rainwater harvesting systems, waste-to-energy conversion technologies, and economic feasibility analysis for housing affordability. Graduates emerge equipped to develop adaptable housing solutions that address urban growth challenges, implement community engagement strategies, and create environmentally conscious housing that protects occupant health and livelihood while contributing to climate action initiatives.

MS6_N1- E-course R.Korsakiene.description: The course equips students with the interdisciplinary knowledge and skills to design, implement, and manage a human-centered cognitive buildings that prioritize occupant well-being, sustainability, and innovation. Topics cover fundamentals of human needs, health, and wellness in buildings, using advanced technologies. International case studies provide insights into diverse design strategies, while modules on sustainability highlight the benefits of resource efficiency and productivity improvements in workplaces. The risks and challenges of human-centered buildings, including cybersecurity, costs, and user acceptance are analysed. Other topics include ethical and privacy concerns and project management perspectives. Future trends such as AI, digital twins, and adaptive systems are explored.
MS6_N1- E-course R.Korsakiene.enhanced_description: Human-centered cognitive building technology for enhanced well-being and workplace productivity - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in designing intelligent buildings that adapt to human needs while optimizing resource efficiency and sustainability. Students master AI-driven building systems, digital twin integration, and adaptive infrastructure that responds to occupant behavior patterns and wellness requirements. The curriculum covers cybersecurity protocols, user acceptance strategies, building evaluation methodologies, and ethical frameworks for privacy-conscious smart environments. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing cognitive building technologies that enhance workplace productivity, reduce environmental impact, and create healthier indoor environments while addressing the complex challenges of user adoption and system integration in modern architecture.

MS6_N6- E-course Naimaviciene.description: The course introduces the smart city aspect, as well as smart cities and building technologies. It analyses the benefits and challenges of smart buildings. Examples of smart cities around the world are given to better understand smart cities, construction and society and their implementation. The course also covers other topics such as smart cities; construction, the application of smart systems in smart cities and building construction (home automation; health monitoring; assistive objects, etc.).
MS6_N6- E-course Naimaviciene.enhanced_description: Smart city and Society 5.0 technology for next-generation urban environments - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in creating intelligent urban ecosystems that integrate advanced technologies for sustainable, human-centered communities. Students master smart city concepts, digital infrastructure development, and Construction 5.0 technologies that enable connected, responsive urban environments. The curriculum covers AI-driven urban planning, circular economy practices, smart energy systems, intelligent farming, and augmented reality applications for cities. Graduates emerge equipped to implement Society 5.0 principles, develop smart mobility solutions, manage urban waste systems, and create resilient, disaster-prepared communities that balance technological advancement with human well-being and environmental sustainability.

MS6_N8- E-course N_Banaitiene.course_title: Big data analytics predicting sustainable and healthy housing
MS6_N8- E-course N_Banaitiene.description: This course explores how big data analytics can be used to predict and promote sustainable and healthy housing. Using large data sets that cover energy consumption, indoor air quality, and building materials, students will learn to develop predictive models to identify potential problems and optimize building performance. The course will cover essential data science concepts such as data collection, data exploration and visualization, and data modeling, applied to the specific context of housing. Students will gain hands-on experience analyzing real-world housing data, interpreting results, and drawing actionable insights to inform sustainable building design and policy decisions.
MS6_N8- E-course N_Banaitiene.enhanced_description: Big data analytics technology for sustainable housing optimization and health prediction - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in leveraging large-scale datasets to develop predictive models that enhance building performance and occupant well-being. Students master data collection methods, visualization techniques, and predictive modeling algorithms specifically applied to housing analytics. The curriculum covers energy consumption prediction, indoor air quality modeling, building material analysis, and maintenance needs forecasting using advanced data science methodologies. Graduates emerge skilled in interpreting complex housing datasets, implementing data-driven decision-making frameworks, and developing analytics solutions that optimize resource efficiency, promote healthy living environments, and inform sustainable construction policies through actionable insights derived from real-world building performance data.

MS9_N3-E-course D.Kalibatas.course_title: Green house by using IoT and cloud computing
MS9_N3-E-course D.Kalibatas.description: This course delves into the innovative world of construction robotics and drones, exploring their transformative potential in the construction industry. Students will gain insights into the latest technologies, applications, and the future possibilities of these advanced tools.
MS9_N3-E-course D.Kalibatas.enhanced_description: Construction robotics and drone technology for automated building systems and site monitoring - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in implementing robotic automation and unmanned aerial vehicles for enhanced construction productivity and safety. Students master operation of construction robots, drone piloting for site inspection, topographical mapping, and integration of automated systems into construction workflows. The curriculum covers safety protocols, regulatory compliance, emerging construction technologies, and predictive maintenance applications for robotic equipment. Graduates emerge skilled in deploying site inspection robots, utilizing drones for aerial surveying, and implementing automated building systems that revolutionize construction efficiency, reduce labor costs, and enhance project management capabilities through advanced technological integration.

MS9_N16- E-course D.Bačinskas.course_title: Smart systems for real-time monitoring of existing structures
MS9_N16- E-course D.Bačinskas.description: This digital course offers comprehensive knowledge and practical experience in smart monitoring systems for existing structures, spanning basic, intermediate, and advanced levels. Participants will learn about the principles and applications of real-time structural monitoring systems. The course covers an introduction to smart monitoring systems, exploring various sensors used in structural monitoring, methods of data collection from sensors, and real-time data analytics. Participants will study structural health monitoring (SHM) systems for continuous assessment and failure prevention, and learn to apply AI and data analytics for anomaly detection and decision-making. Additionally, the course delves into predictive maintenance strategies that leverage real-time data to optimize repairs, case studies of smart monitoring in critical infrastructure, and the importance of cybersecurity in protecting system integrity. Finally, it examines emerging trends in advanced sensors, AI-driven diagnostics, and blockchain technologies shaping the future of smart monitoring systems.
MS9_N16- E-course D.Bačinskas.enhanced_description: Smart monitoring technology for real-time structural health assessment and infrastructure safety - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in implementing sensor networks, data acquisition systems, and AI-driven analytics for continuous structure monitoring. Students master deployment of strain gauges, accelerometers, temperature sensors, and IoT wireless networks that enable real-time structural integrity assessment. The curriculum covers structural health monitoring (SHM) systems, AI anomaly detection algorithms, predictive maintenance strategies, and cybersecurity protocols for monitoring infrastructure. Graduates emerge skilled in developing smart monitoring solutions for bridges, buildings, and critical infrastructure that predict maintenance needs, prevent failures, and optimize repair schedules through advanced data analytics and emerging blockchain technologies for enhanced system reliability.

MS10_N7- E-course N.Lepkova.course_title: Green house by using IoT and cloud computing
MS10_N7- E-course N.Lepkova.description: The course provides introduction to green aspect, as well as to greenhouse technology. The benefits and problems of green buildings are analysed. Green Buildings examples in Lithuania and other countries are provided for better understanding of greenhouse technology and its implementation. Other topics are analysed in the course: Green house by using IoT and cloud computing; green building certification (BREEM, LEAD and etc.); Smart systems application in green buildings (home automation system; health monitoring system; weather reporting system and etc.).
MS10_N7- E-course N.Lepkova.enhanced_description: Green building technology for sustainable and environmentally conscious construction - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in implementing IoT-enabled smart systems and cloud computing solutions for energy-efficient building management. Students master green building certification processes (BREEAM, LEED), building automation systems, and smart sensor networks that optimize resource consumption and enhance occupant comfort. The curriculum covers IoT-based health monitoring, weather reporting systems, smart anti-theft technologies, and intelligent waste management solutions for sustainable buildings. Graduates emerge skilled in developing connected healthcare systems, smart cradle technologies, and streetlight monitoring solutions that contribute to environmentally responsible architecture while improving building performance and user experience through advanced digital integration.

MS10_N10-E-course A.RimkusV.Gribniak.description: This digital course provides knowledge and practical experience at three levels (basic, intermediate, and advanced) in developing and applying composite materials. The course objectives are the following: to deliver into the composite materials technology and characterization; to familiarize with principles of structural design, materials characterization, and choice of constituents; to relate the time-dependent changes of materials properties and internal structure of composite with structural resistance. The course focuses on efficiently utilizing and combining advanced and recycled materials to reduce the volume of traditional materials, reducing natural resource demands. The application examples include fiber-reinforced cement-based and polymeric composites, recycled and biodegradable polymers, and thin-walled metal components in different combinations. The course also describes additive manufacturing principles as the most innovative, tailorable, and waste-diminishing fabrication technique.
MS10_N10-E-course A.RimkusV.Gribniak.enhanced_description: Composite materials technology for sustainable structural applications and advanced manufacturing - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in developing and applying fiber-reinforced, polymeric, and recycled composite materials for environmentally conscious construction. Students master materials characterization techniques, structural design principles, and additive manufacturing processes that enable waste-reducing fabrication methods. The curriculum covers long-term performance analysis, material aging processes, and 3D printing technologies that optimize composite efficiency while reducing natural resource consumption. Graduates emerge skilled in creating innovative composite solutions that combine advanced materials with recycled components, implementing sustainable structural systems that minimize environmental impact while maximizing performance through advanced material engineering and waste-diminishing fabrication techniques.

MS10_N11- E-course J.Malaiškienė-R.Boris.course_title: Green and friendly house building materials based on waste
MS10_N11- E-course J.Malaiškienė-R.Boris.description: This digital course is designed to provide knowledge and practical experience in 3 levels (basic, intermediate, and advanced) on green building materials technology, benefits, and properties with a strong focus on the use of waste materials to reduce CO₂ emissions. In this course it will be analysed basics of green building materials; types of waste, that can be used in building materials; safety and environmental considerations, challenges, and solutions in using waste materials for house building materials; criteria of using green building materials in construction; eco-friendly concretes with reduced water and cement content in which some amount of cement or aggregates are replaced by various waste; geopolymers; thermal insulation materials with various waste; composite boards and roofing materials based on waste.
MS10_N11- E-course J.Malaiškienė-R.Boris.enhanced_description: Green building materials technology for waste utilization and CO₂ emission reduction - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in transforming waste materials into sustainable construction resources while minimizing environmental impact. Students master construction waste processing techniques, XRF and XRD analysis methods, and safety protocols for developing eco-friendly building materials from recycled components. The curriculum covers eco-friendly concrete production, geopolymer binder development, waste-based thermal insulation, and composite board manufacturing while addressing material toxicity and leaching concerns. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing waste-based roofing materials, supplementary cementitious materials, and sustainable construction solutions that significantly reduce carbon emissions through innovative waste-to-resource conversion strategies and advanced material characterization techniques.

MS10_N12-E-course G.Kaklauskas.course_title: Nonlinear mechanics of low-carbon concrete structures
MS10_N12-E-course G.Kaklauskas.description: The non-linear deformation of reinforced concrete structures may result in several times higher displacements in comparison to linear elastic analysis. This is mainly caused by the complex interaction of reinforcement and concrete, cracking and time-dependant effects of creep and shrinkage. In the present course, main aspects of nonlinear behaviour of reinforced concrete are discussed along with the analysis methods.
MS10_N12-E-course G.Kaklauskas.enhanced_description: Nonlinear mechanics technology for accurate structural analysis of low-carbon concrete systems - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in analyzing complex concrete behavior through advanced finite element methods and material modeling techniques. Students master concrete microstructure analysis, reinforcement-concrete bond mechanics, and cracking analysis methods that predict structural performance under various loading conditions. The curriculum covers physical and geometrical nonlinearity, iterative analysis methods, layer section models, and time-dependent effects including creep and shrinkage phenomena. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing nonlinear finite element analysis, stress-strain evaluation, and deformation prediction techniques that enable accurate structural design of sustainable low-carbon concrete constructions while accounting for complex material interactions and long-term performance characteristics.

MS10_N13- E-course D.Bačinskas.course_title: Zero Waste: Designing structures that are easily reused and recycled
MS10_N13- E-course D.Bačinskas.description: This digital course provides comprehensive knowledge and practical experience in zero-waste technology for structures, covering three levels: basic, intermediate, and advanced. Participants will explore the principles of zero-waste design, focusing on creating structures that minimize waste throughout their lifecycle. The course includes an introduction to zero-waste design; strategies for reusing materials and components without generating waste; modular design techniques for creating flexible, scalable, and reconfigurable structures; and the cradle-to-cradle approach for continuous material reuse. Additionally, it covers methods to maximize resource efficiency, analyzes case studies of zero-waste buildings to highlight successes and lessons learned, and examines future trends and technologies in advancing zero-waste architecture.
MS10_N13- E-course D.Bačinskas.enhanced_description: Zero waste design technology for circular construction and sustainable material lifecycle management - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in creating structures that minimize waste through modular construction, design for disassembly, and cradle-to-cradle principles. Students master material reuse strategies, component reconfiguration techniques, and resource efficiency optimization that enable flexible and scalable building systems. The curriculum covers circular construction methodologies, adaptive reuse design, and sustainable architecture case studies that demonstrate successful waste minimization approaches. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing future zero waste technologies and sustainable design innovations that transform traditional construction practices into environmentally responsible systems maximizing material lifecycle value while eliminating waste generation.

MS10_N14- E-course A.Šneideris.course_title: Material choice in designing low-carbon concrete structures
MS10_N14- E-course A.Šneideris.description: This digital course offers a comprehensive exploration of low-carbon concrete design through three progressive levels: basic, intermediate, and advanced. It provides in-depth knowledge and practical experience in the use of sustainable building materials, innovative cement alternatives, and cutting-edge technologies such as alkali-activated materials (AAMs) and geopolymer concrete. Participants will also examine the integration of biogenic materials, strategies for carbon footprint reduction, carbon capture methods, and energy-efficient production processes. Designed for a broad audience, this course empowers learners to advance sustainable construction practices and contribute to environmentally responsible development.
MS10_N14- E-course A.Šneideris.enhanced_description: Low-carbon concrete materials technology for sustainable construction and carbon footprint minimization - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in developing innovative cement alternatives and advanced concrete solutions that significantly reduce environmental impact. Students master alkali-activated materials, geopolymer concrete technology, and biogenic material integration that transform traditional concrete production into sustainable practices. The curriculum covers carbon capture technologies, energy-efficient manufacturing processes, and sustainable cement alternatives that minimize CO₂ emissions while maintaining structural performance. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing carbon reduction strategies, environmental concrete design methodologies, and cutting-edge material science solutions that advance sustainable construction practices and contribute to environmentally responsible development through innovative low-carbon building technologies.

MS10_N17- E-course J.Valivonis, A.Jokūba.description: This digital course is designed to provide knowledge and practical experience in 3 levels (basic, intermediate, and advanced) to learn the calculation methods of composite structures under different effects and in the cases of rigid and flexible connection between layers. The course provides information to recognize and analyse problems related to the design of composite structures, apply advanced methods, and make rational structural decisions. Additionally, the course focuses on combining different eco-friendly materials in composite structures using the best mechanical properties and reducing the amount of materials that cause the highest foot print of CO2.
MS10_N17- E-course J.Valivonis, A.Jokūba.enhanced_description: Composite structures design technology for sustainable construction and CO₂ footprint reduction - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in calculating and designing eco-friendly composite structures that optimize mechanical properties while minimizing environmental impact. Students master layer interaction analysis, stress-strain evaluation methods, and partial stiffness calculations for both rigid and flexible layer connections in structural systems. The curriculum covers lightweight composite design, sandwich panel engineering, steel-concrete composite structures, and stiffening element optimization that enable sustainable building solutions. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing eco-friendly material combinations, structural decision optimization, and advanced composite calculation methodologies that reduce CO₂ emissions while maintaining superior structural performance through innovative material engineering and sustainable design principles.

MS10_N18-E-course A.Daniunas A.Mudrov.course_title: Modern sustainable buildings and their structures of steel, wood and composites
MS10_N18-E-course A.Daniunas A.Mudrov.description: The aim of this digital course is to equip students with basic understanding of the environmental implications of construction material choices, emphasizing timber, concrete, steel, and their composites. The course fosters an appreciation of wood as a renewable resource and its significance in sustainable construction. Students will develop the ability to apply lifecycle assessment (LCA) methodologies and normative frameworks to evaluate material sustainability and integrate principles of recycling and the circular economy into innovative building design solutions.
MS10_N18-E-course A.Daniunas A.Mudrov.enhanced_description: Sustainable building materials technology for environmentally conscious construction and circular economy implementation - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in evaluating and selecting timber, concrete, steel, and composite materials based on environmental impact assessment and lifecycle performance analysis. Students master lifecycle assessment (LCA) methodologies, forest carbon sequestration principles, and cross-laminated timber (CLT) technology that enable sustainable material choices. The curriculum covers material renewability evaluation, durability assessment, and circular economy integration strategies that minimize environmental impact while maximizing structural longevity. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing normative frameworks for sustainability assessment, material recycling solutions, and innovative building designs that balance performance requirements with environmental responsibility through advanced material selection and comprehensive lifecycle optimization techniques.

MS16_N9_E-course S.Skuodis N. Dirgeliene.description: This digital course is designed to provide knowledge and practical experience in 3 levels (basic, intermediate, and advanced) on soil testing of building foundations as precisely as possible. Geotechnical investigations provide essential information about the soil's physical and mechanical properties, such as compressibility, shear strength and bearing capacity. Accurate characterization of these properties helps in: selecting appropriate foundation types; determining the load-bearing capacity of the ground; designing foundations that minimize settlement and prevent failure. Poor understanding of soil conditions can lead to foundation failure, resulting in severe structural issues such as cracking, tilting, or collapse. This course would enable to achieve the economy of materials and labour expenditures for the construction of foundations. In this course, students'll learn how to test soil accurately, analyze the results, and apply this data to make informed engineering decisions.
MS16_N9_E-course S.Skuodis N. Dirgeliene.enhanced_description: Geotechnical laboratory testing technology for accurate soil characterization and foundation engineering - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in performing precise soil testing procedures that determine critical physical and mechanical properties for building foundation design. Students master soil mechanics fundamentals, granulometric analysis, moisture content testing, permeability evaluation, and Atterberg limits determination that inform optimal foundation selection. The curriculum covers Proctor compaction testing, shear strength analysis, compressibility assessment, and consolidation evaluation methods that prevent foundation failures and optimize structural performance. Graduates emerge skilled in implementing geotechnical testing protocols, analyzing soil behavior patterns, and applying engineering data to design foundations that minimize settlement, maximize load-bearing capacity, and achieve economical material and labor usage in construction projects.

MS16_N15-E-course J.Valivonis-J.Šlaitas.course_title: Application of circular economy principles in structural design
MS16_N15-E-course J.Valivonis-J.Šlaitas.description: This digital course introduces students to the principles of circular economy in structural design and construction. It focuses on sustainable approaches to structural engineering, including life cycle assessment, material reuse, and innovative strengthening techniques for recycled structures. The course combines theoretical knowledge with practical applications, emphasizing environmental impact reduction and resource efficiency in construction.
MS16_N15-E-course J.Valivonis-J.Šlaitas.enhanced_description: Circular economy technology for sustainable structural design and resource-efficient construction - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in implementing circular economy principles through lifecycle assessment, material reuse strategies, and innovative reinforcement techniques for recycled structures. Students master environmental impact analysis methods, construction material recycling protocols, and design for disassembly principles that maximize resource efficiency and minimize waste. The curriculum covers structural strengthening techniques, material recovery systems, regulatory frameworks for sustainable construction, and solutions for retrofitting recycled structures. Graduates emerge skilled in applying circular design solutions that transform traditional construction practices into environmentally responsible systems while maintaining structural integrity and performance through innovative engineering approaches and comprehensive sustainability methodologies.

! Nr. 1_A.Zajacs_WP3_MS9.course_title: Energy: Dynamics Energy and Indoor Air Quality Simulation
! Nr. 1_A.Zajacs_WP3_MS9.description: This course encompasses the principles of energy dynamics and indoor air quality (IAQ) simulation, focusing on modeling techniques, IAQ parameters, and regulatory implications. Students will use advanced simulation software (e.g., IDA-ICE, OpenStudio) to create and analyze models to evaluate energy efficiency and IAQ in buildings. Digital skills relevant to the construction and engineering sectors, such as building information modeling (BIM), data analytics, and simulation software, will be emphasized.
! Nr. 1_A.Zajacs_WP3_MS9.enhanced_description: Technology for building energy simulation and indoor air quality analysis - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in IDA-ICE and OpenStudio platforms for energy dynamics principles and IAQ parameter monitoring. Students will master advanced building energy flow analysis techniques, energy efficiency modeling, and building information modeling (BIM) integration for energy modeling techniques. The curriculum focuses on practical applications of energy simulation optimization, building performance assessment, and energy efficiency standards development. Participants will gain hands-on experience with energy simulation tools for IAQ health impacts evaluation, energy dynamics case studies, and regulatory frameworks compliance. The program emphasizes advanced simulation methods for real-world building energy analysis, energy modeling troubleshooting, and long-term performance assessment strategies using cutting-edge simulation software technologies.

! Nr. 2_A.Prozuments_WP3_MS6.course_title: Solar Energy Systems Design and Simulation
! Nr. 2_A.Prozuments_WP3_MS6.description: This course provides an overview of solar energy system design and simulation with a focus on photovoltaic (PV) and solar thermal systems. It covers solar energy fundamentals, system design, optimization, performance assessment, and case studies, preparing students to design, size, simulate and evaluate efficient solar energy solutions.
! Nr. 2_A.Prozuments_WP3_MS6.enhanced_description: Technology for renewable energy system design and solar energy simulation - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in photovoltaic (PV) systems and solar thermal systems design using advanced simulation software platforms. Students will master Polysun, PV Sol, T Sol, and TRNSYS software for solar energy system design, PV system optimization, and solar thermal optimization applications. The curriculum focuses on practical solar energy simulation techniques for grid-connected PV systems, off-grid PV systems, and passive solar thermal solutions. Participants will gain hands-on experience with solar energy fundamentals, performance assessment methodologies, and life cycle assessment (LCA) for environmental impact evaluation. The program emphasizes solar energy economics analysis, EU solar energy policies compliance, and solar energy regulations implementation using cutting-edge design tools and simulation technologies for comprehensive solar energy solutions.

Nr. 3_A.Prozuments_WP4_MS10.course_title: Indoor Air Quality and Thermal Comfort – Requirements and Assessment
Nr. 3_A.Prozuments_WP4_MS10.description: This course provides an in-depth examination of indoor air quality (IAQ) and thermal comfort, focusing on the requirements and assessment techniques. Students will learn about key IAQ and comfort metrics, measurement tools, regulatory standards, and digital skills essential for effective monitoring and assessment. The course includes hands-on training with modeling and simulation software to optimize indoor environments in various building types, highlighting practical applications in ensuring health and comfort in housing.
Nr. 3_A.Prozuments_WP4_MS10.enhanced_description: Technology for indoor environmental monitoring and thermal comfort optimization - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in indoor air quality (IAQ) fundamentals and thermal comfort principles using advanced assessment methods and monitoring tools. Students will master IAQ assessment methods, thermal comfort monitoring techniques, and data analysis techniques for optimizing indoor environmental conditions. The curriculum focuses on practical IAQ optimization strategies, thermal comfort optimization approaches, and IAQ modeling software integration for building IAQ integration projects. Participants will gain hands-on experience with thermal comfort simulation tools, IAQ regulatory standards compliance, and comfort standards implementation using digital IAQ assessment tools. The program emphasizes health impact assessment methodologies, smart building technologies integration, and IAQ cost-benefit analysis for ensuring optimal indoor environmental quality in diverse building types.

Nr. 4_A.Prozuments_WP4_MS13.course_title: Housing: Thermal performance of well-insulated building envelopes
Nr. 4_A.Prozuments_WP4_MS13.description: Within the framework of this course the thermal performance of well-insulated building envelopes is examined in a detailed manner, emphasizing energy efficiency, material properties, design considerations, and practical applications. Students will gain knowledge and analytical skills into the principles of heat transfer, thermal properties of materials, and the building insulation materials, technologies. The course includes case studies and exercises in assessing and optimizing insulation performance in various building types.
Nr. 4_A.Prozuments_WP4_MS13.enhanced_description: Technology for building envelope optimization and thermal performance enhancement - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in building insulation materials and thermal performance analysis using advanced simulation tools. Students will master heat transfer principles, insulation material properties evaluation, and building envelope design strategies for optimal energy efficiency optimization. The curriculum focuses on practical insulation performance assessment techniques, thermal monitoring methodologies, and advanced insulation technologies integration. Participants will gain hands-on experience with building system integration approaches, hygrothermal analysis methods, and DELPHIN simulation software for moisture transfer analysis and thermal bridge analysis applications. The program emphasizes building insulation BIM integration, insulation cost-effectiveness evaluation, and environmental impact assessment for comprehensive thermal insulation solutions in modern building construction.

! Nr. 4_A.Borodinecs_WP4_MS13.course_title: Thermal performance of well insulated building envelopes
! Nr. 4_A.Borodinecs_WP4_MS13.description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of heat and moisture transfer processes in modern, highly insulated building envelopes. Students will learn to analyze and design constructions that ensure optimal thermal comfort, energy efficiency, and durability. Topics include heat transfer mechanisms, boundary conditions, thermal bridges, and the performance of thermally inhomogeneous structures such as wooden frame walls. The course also introduces methods for evaluating hygrothermal behaviour, including interstitial condensation risks and moisture transport within building assemblies. Practical sessions involve modelling and simulation tools.
! Nr. 4_A.Borodinecs_WP4_MS13.enhanced_description: Technology for advanced building envelope analysis and thermal bridge optimization - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in heat transfer mechanisms and moisture transfer processes for modern building envelope analysis applications. Students will master thermal bridge calculation techniques, boundary conditions analysis, and wooden frame construction evaluation for optimal thermal performance optimization. The curriculum focuses on practical air tightness testing methods, blower door testing procedures, and infrared thermography applications for U-value monitoring and interstitial condensation detection. Participants will gain hands-on experience with Glazer calculation methods, dynamic heat-moisture transfer modeling, and building renovation challenges assessment. The program emphasizes building envelope testing protocols, thermal performance optimization strategies, and building envelope analysis using advanced simulation tools for comprehensive building physics solutions.

Nr. 5_J.Pomerancevs_WP4_MS10.description: This course covers the aspects, principles and types of non-refrigerant cooling systems, including passive and evaporative cooling, desiccant cooling, and other sustainable methods. Students will learn fundamental principles, technological applications, design strategies, and regulatory frameworks. Emphasis is placed on practical applications and integrating these systems with modern building designs, and colling capacity calculation and system simulation.
Nr. 5_J.Pomerancevs_WP4_MS10.enhanced_description: Technology for sustainable cooling system design and non-refrigerant cooling optimization - this course delivers comprehensive expertise in evaporative cooling technology and passive cooling methods using advanced desiccant cooling systems and radiant cooling applications. Students will master ground cooling systems, phase change materials (PCMs) implementation, and night ventilation strategies for optimal heat recovery ventilation integration. The curriculum focuses on practical cooling system regulations compliance, cooling performance metrics evaluation, and cooling system optimization techniques for human-centric cooling design applications. Participants will gain hands-on experience with building cooling integration approaches, cooling system troubleshooting methodologies, and cooling system simulation tools.
